title: Investigation of Hillary Clinton's Emails - CIA Records

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Investigation of Hillary Clinton's Emails - CIA Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Central Intelligence Agency
Office of Information Policy
Washington, DC 20505

To Whom It May Concern:

Subject: Freedom of Information Act Request - Investigation of Hillary Clinton's Emails

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), I hereby request the following records:

All records, reports, memos, or communications related to the Central Intelligence Agency's (CIA) investigation or involvement, if any, in the matter concerning Hillary Clinton's private email server and the handling of classified information during her tenure as Secretary of State from January 21, 2009, to February 1, 2013.
Any internal reviews, investigations, or assessments conducted by the CIA regarding the potential security implications of Secretary Clinton's use of a private email server during the aforementioned time frame.
Any correspondence or communications between the CIA and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) or the Department of State regarding the investigation of Hillary Clinton's emails, specifically from January 21, 2009, to February 1, 2013.
Any declarations or statements made by the CIA, whether publicly or internally, regarding the classification status of documents related to the investigation of Hillary Clinton's emails during the specified time period.
In particular, I request any records, correspondence, or communications involving the following key individuals who held prominent positions within the CIA during the specified time frame:

CIA Director:

Leon Panetta (January 21, 2009 - June 30, 2011)
David Petraeus (September 6, 2011 - November 9, 2012)
Michael Morell (Acting Director, November 9, 2012 - March 8, 2013)
CIA Deputy Director:

Stephen R. Kappes (January 21, 2009 - May 14, 2010)
Michael Morell (May 14, 2010 - August 9, 2013)
CIA Chief of Staff:

Jeremy Bash (January 21, 2009 - August 16, 2011)
Benjamin Powell (August 16, 2011 - February 1, 2013)
These individuals played significant roles within the CIA during the specified time period, and any records involving their communications, decision-making, or actions related to the investigation of Hillary Clinton's emails are of particular interest.

In support of this FOIA request, I would like to reference the following court cases that emphasize the importance of public access to information under the FOIA:

Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW) v. U.S. Department of Justice, 746 F.3d 1082 (D.C. Cir. 2014): The court emphasized the broad scope of the FOIA, stating that it is not limited to the specific details of an investigation but also covers information regarding the existence and status of ongoing investigations.
New York Times Co. v. United States, 403 U.S. 713 (1971): The Supreme Court recognized the need for government transparency and accountability, especially when matters of public concern are involved.

Additionally, I would like to draw your attention to a tweet posted by former President Donald Trump on October 6, 2020, in which he refers to the declaration or declassification of certain documents related to the investigation of Hillary Clinton's emails. For your reference, I have attached a screenshot of the tweet to this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: Records on Public Complaints Related to 'Mister Rogers' Neighborhood (1968-2001)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Records on Public Complaints Related to 'Mister Rogers' Neighborhood (1968-2001)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Federal Communications Commission
Office of the Secretary
45 L Street NE
Washington, DC 20554

To Whom It May Concern:

Subject: Freedom of Information Act Request - Records of Complaints Related to "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood"

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), I hereby request the following records:

All complaints received by the Federal Communications Commission regarding the television program "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood" from its inception in 1968 to its conclusion in 2001.
Any internal communications, memos, or other documentation relating to these complaints.
Any actions taken by the FCC in response to these complaints.
This request is not being made for commercial purposes, but in the interest of understanding public sentiment and responses towards this iconic television program.

Please note that the U.S. Supreme Court in NLRB v. Robbins Tire Co., 437 U.S. 214 (1978), affirmed that the core purpose of the FOIA is to contribute to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: NYPD Records on Press Credential Applications from 2010 to Present

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: NYPD Records on Press Credential Applications from 2010 to Present
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

New York Police Department
FOIL Unit
1 Police Plaza, Room 110-C
New York, NY 10038

To Whom It May Concern:

Subject: Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) Request - Records of Press Credential Applications

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, Article 6 of the Public Officers Law, I hereby request the following records:

A database or spreadsheet detailing all applications for press credentials submitted to the New York Police Department from January 1, 2010, to the present. For each application, please include:
The date of application
The name of the applicant (if not considered private information)
The media organization the applicant represented at the time of application
Whether the application was approved or denied
If denied, the reasons for the denial.

Please provide this information in a machine-readable format, such as Excel or CSV.

This request is not made for commercial purposes, but in the interest of understanding the process and criteria by which press credentials are granted or denied by the New York Police Department.


Please note that the U.S. Supreme Court in NLRB v. Robbins Tire Co., 437 U.S. 214 (1978), affirmed that the core purpose of the FOIA is to contribute to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government. Similarly, in Scott, Sardano & Pomeranz v. Records Access Officer of the City of Syracuse, 65 N.Y.2d 294 (1985), the New York Court of Appeals emphasized the public's right to access records under the New York FOIL.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter
